p: As GP, ML output focuses on optimizing the predictive ability, or ‘recall’ rate, of a given classification (e.g., tolerant vs. susceptible accessions) ( Figure 2 and Table 2), usually relying on a ‘supervised’ training with ‘labeled’ data (e.g., accessions for which drought/heat [ 127] tolerance are already measured or environmentally-estimated, Table 2). An advantage of ML is that it deals more efficiently with high-dimensional inputs of heterogeneous variables ( Figure 1g) (‘features’) without a priori knowledge of their joint probability distribution [ 128], bypassing the ‘curse of dimensionality’ and a complex systems thinking ( Figure 1l,m).
